== Overview

Official low-level client for Elasticsearch. It's goal is to provide common
ground for all Elasticsearch-related code in Python; because of this it tries
to be opinion-free and very extendable. The full documentation is available at
http://elasticsearch-py.rtfd.org/

It can be installed with:

[source,sh]
------------------------------------
pip install elasticsearch
------------------------------------

=== Example use

Simple use-case:

[source,python]
------------------------------------
>>> from datetime import datetime
>>> from elasticsearch import Elasticsearch

# by default we connect to localhost:9200
>>> es = Elasticsearch()

# datetimes will be serialized
>>> es.index(index="my-index", doc_type="test-type", id=42, body={"any": "data", "timestamp": datetime.now()})
{u'_id': u'42', u'_index': u'my-index', u'_type': u'test-type', u'_version': 1, u'ok': True}

# but not deserialized
>>> es.get(index="my-index", doc_type="test-type", id=42)['_source']
{u'any': u'data', u'timestamp': u'2013-05-12T19:45:31.804229'}
------------------------------------

[NOTE] 
All the API calls map the raw REST api as closely as possible, including
the distinction between required and optional arguments to the calls. This
means that the code makes distinction between positional and keyword arguments;
we, however, recommend that people use keyword arguments for all calls for
consistency and safety.

=== Features

The client's features include:

* translating basic Python data types to and from json (datetimes are not
  decoded for performance reasons)

* configurable automatic discovery of cluster nodes

* persistent connections

* load balancing (with pluggable selection strategy) across all available nodes

* failed connection penalization (time based - failed connections won't be
  retried until a timeout is reached)

* thread safety

* pluggable architecture

== Client

You can use the *java client* in multiple ways:

* Perform standard <<index_,index>>, <<get,get>>,
  <<delete,delete>> and <<search,search>> operations on an
  existing cluster
* Perform administrative tasks on a running cluster
* Start full nodes when you want to run Elasticsearch embedded in your
  own application  or when you want to launch unit or integration tests

Obtaining an elasticsearch `Client` is simple. The most common way to
get a client is by:

1.  creating an embedded link:#nodeclient[`Node`] that acts as a node
within a cluster
2.  requesting a `Client` from your embedded `Node`.

Another manner is by creating a link:#transportclient[`TransportClient`]
that connects to a cluster.

*Important:*

______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
Please note that you are encouraged to use the same version on client
and cluster sides. You may hit some incompatibilities issues when mixing
major versions.
______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________


[[node-client]]
=== Node Client

Instantiating a node based client is the simplest way to get a `Client`
that can execute operations against elasticsearch.

[source,java]
--------------------------------------------------
import static org.elasticsearch.node.NodeBuilder.*;

// on startup

Node node = nodeBuilder().node();
Client client = node.client();

// on shutdown

node.close();
--------------------------------------------------

When you start a `Node`, it joins an elasticsearch cluster. You can have
different clusters by simple setting the `cluster.name` setting, or
explicitly using the `clusterName` method on the builder.

You can define `cluster.name` in `/src/main/resources/elasticsearch.yml`
dir in your project. As long as `elasticsearch.yml` is present in the
classloader, it will be used when you start your node.

[source,java]
--------------------------------------------------
cluster.name=yourclustername
--------------------------------------------------

Or in Java:

[source,java]
--------------------------------------------------
Node node = nodeBuilder().clusterName("yourclustername").node();
Client client = node.client();
--------------------------------------------------

The benefit of using the `Client` is the fact that operations are
automatically routed to the node(s) the operations need to be executed
on, without performing a "double hop". For example, the index operation
will automatically be executed on the shard that it will end up existing
at.

When you start a `Node`, the most important decision is whether it
should hold data or not. In other words, should indices and shards be
allocated to it. Many times we would like to have the clients just be
clients, without shards being allocated to them. This is simple to
configure by setting either `node.data` setting to `false` or
`node.client` to `true` (the `NodeBuilder` respective helper methods on
it):

[source,java]
--------------------------------------------------
import static org.elasticsearch.node.NodeBuilder.*;

// on startup

Node node = nodeBuilder().client(true).node();
Client client = node.client();

// on shutdown

node.close();
--------------------------------------------------

Another common usage is to start the `Node` and use the `Client` in
unit/integration tests. In such a case, we would like to start a "local"
`Node` (with a "local" discovery and transport). Again, this is just a
matter of a simple setting when starting the `Node`. Note, "local" here
means local on the JVM (well, actually class loader) level, meaning that
two *local* servers started within the same JVM will discover themselves
and form a cluster.

[source,java]
--------------------------------------------------
import static org.elasticsearch.node.NodeBuilder.*;

// on startup

Node node = nodeBuilder().local(true).node();
Client client = node.client();

// on shutdown

node.close();
--------------------------------------------------


[[transport-client]]
=== Transport Client

The `TransportClient` connects remotely to an elasticsearch cluster
using the transport module. It does not join the cluster, but simply
gets one or more initial transport addresses and communicates with them
in round robin fashion on each action (though most actions will probably
be "two hop" operations).

[source,java]
--------------------------------------------------
// on startup

Client client = new TransportClient()
        .addTransportAddress(new InetSocketTransportAddress("host1", 9300))
        .addTransportAddress(new InetSocketTransportAddress("host2", 9300));

// on shutdown

client.close();
--------------------------------------------------

Note that you have to set the cluster name if you use one different to
"elasticsearch":

[source,java]
--------------------------------------------------
Settings settings = ImmutableSettings.settingsBuilder()
        .put("cluster.name", "myClusterName").build();
Client client =    new TransportClient(settings);
//Add transport addresses and do something with the client...
--------------------------------------------------

Or using `elasticsearch.yml` file as shown in the link:#nodeclient[Node
Client section]

The client allows to sniff the rest of the cluster, and add those into
its list of machines to use. In this case, note that the ip addresses
used will be the ones that the other nodes were started with (the
"publish" address). In order to enable it, set the
`client.transport.sniff` to `true`:

[source,java]
--------------------------------------------------
Settings settings = ImmutableSettings.settingsBuilder()
        .put("client.transport.sniff", true).build();
TransportClient client = new TransportClient(settings);
--------------------------------------------------

Other transport client level settings include:

[cols="<,<",options="header",]
|=======================================================================
|Parameter |Description
|`client.transport.ignore_cluster_name` |Set to `true` to ignore cluster
name validation of connected nodes. (since 0.19.4)

|`client.transport.ping_timeout` |The time to wait for a ping response
from a node. Defaults to `5s`.

|`client.transport.nodes_sampler_interval` |How often to sample / ping
the nodes listed and connected. Defaults to `5s`.
|=======================================================================

== Overview

Official low-level client for Elasticsearch. It's goal is to provide common
ground for all Elasticsearch-related code in Python; because of this it tries
to be opinion-free and very extendable. The full documentation is available at
http://elasticsearch-py.rtfd.org/

It can be installed with:

[source,sh]
------------------------------------
pip install elasticsearch
------------------------------------

=== Example use

Simple use-case:

[source,python]
------------------------------------
>>> from datetime import datetime
>>> from elasticsearch import Elasticsearch

# by default we connect to localhost:9200
>>> es = Elasticsearch()

# datetimes will be serialized
>>> es.index(index="my-index", doc_type="test-type", id=42, body={"any": "data", "timestamp": datetime.now()})
{u'_id': u'42', u'_index': u'my-index', u'_type': u'test-type', u'_version': 1, u'ok': True}

# but not deserialized
>>> es.get(index="my-index", doc_type="test-type", id=42)['_source']
{u'any': u'data', u'timestamp': u'2013-05-12T19:45:31.804229'}
------------------------------------

[NOTE] 
All the API calls map the raw REST api as closely as possible, including
the distinction between required and optional arguments to the calls. This
means that the code makes distinction between positional and keyword arguments;
we, however, recommend that people use keyword arguments for all calls for
consistency and safety.

=== Features

The client's features include:

* translating basic Python data types to and from json (datetimes are not
  decoded for performance reasons)

* configurable automatic discovery of cluster nodes

* persistent connections

* load balancing (with pluggable selection strategy) across all available nodes

* failed connection penalization (time based - failed connections won't be
  retried until a timeout is reached)

* thread safety

* pluggable architecture

{"type":"tool_result","id":"call_4SlEY3wYREtXnH8JotFbz0Kx","messageId":"a62538ed-3025-47c3-8242-11f8168cc1f1","toolId":"","isError":false,"value":"[[index_]]
== Index API

The index API allows one to index a typed JSON document into a specific
index and make it searchable.


[[generate]]
=== Generate JSON document

There are different way of generating JSON document:

* Manually (aka do it yourself) using native `byte[]` or as a `String`

* Using `Map` that will be automatically converted to its JSON
equivalent

* Using a third party library to serialize your beans such as
http://wiki.fasterxml.com/JacksonHome[Jackson]

* Using built-in helpers XContentFactory.jsonBuilder()

Internally, each type is converted to `byte[]` (so a String is converted
to a `byte[]`). Therefore, if the object is in this form already, then
use it. The `jsonBuilder` is highly optimized JSON generator that
directly constructs a `byte[]`.


==== Do It Yourself

Nothing really difficult here but note that you will have to encode
dates regarding to the
{ref}/mapping-date-format.html[Date Format].

[source,java]
--------------------------------------------------
String json = "{" +
        "\"user\":\"kimchy\"," +
        "\"postDate\":\"2013-01-30\"," +
        "\"message\":\"trying out Elastic Search\"," +
    "}";
--------------------------------------------------


[[using-map]]
==== Using Map

Map is a key:values pair collection. It represents very well a JSON
structure:

[source,java]
--------------------------------------------------
Map<String, Object> json = new HashMap<String, Object>();
json.put("user","kimchy");
json.put("postDate",new Date());
json.put("message","trying out Elastic Search");
--------------------------------------------------


[[beans]]
==== Serialize your beans

Elasticsearch already use Jackson but shade it under
`org.elasticsearch.common.jackson` package. +
 So, you can add your own Jackson version in your `pom.xml` file or in
your classpath. See http://wiki.fasterxml.com/JacksonDownload[Jackson
Download Page].

For example:

[source,xml]
--------------------------------------------------
<dependency>
    <groupId>com.fasterxml.jackson.core</groupId>
    <artifactId>jackson-databind</artifactId>
    <version>2.1.3</version>
</dependency>
--------------------------------------------------

Then, you can start serializing your beans to JSON:

[source,java]
--------------------------------------------------
import com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.*;

// instance a json mapper
ObjectMapper mapper = new ObjectMapper(); // create once, reuse

// generate json
String json = mapper.writeValueAsString(yourbeaninstance);
--------------------------------------------------


[[helpers]]
==== Use Elasticsearch helpers

Elasticsearch provides built-in helpers to generate JSON content.

[source,java]
--------------------------------------------------
import static org.elasticsearch.common.xcontent.XContentFactory.*;

XContentBuilder builder = jsonBuilder()
    .startObject()
        .field("user", "kimchy")
        .field("postDate", new Date())
        .field("message", "trying out Elastic Search")
    .endObject()
--------------------------------------------------

Note that you can also add arrays with `startArray(String)` and
`endArray()` methods. By the way, `field` method +
 accept many object types. You can pass directly numbers, dates and even
other XContentBuilder objects.

If you need to see the generated JSON content, you can use the
@string()@method.

[source,java]
--------------------------------------------------
String json = builder.string();
--------------------------------------------------


[[index-doc]]
=== Index document

The following example indexes a JSON document into an index called
twitter, under a type called tweet, with id valued 1:

[source,java]
--------------------------------------------------
import static org.elasticsearch.common.xcontent.XContentFactory.*;

IndexResponse response = client.prepareIndex("twitter", "tweet", "1")
        .setSource(jsonBuilder()
                    .startObject()
                        .field("user", "kimchy")
                        .field("postDate", new Date())
                        .field("message", "trying out Elastic Search")
                    .endObject()
                  )
        .execute()
        .actionGet();
--------------------------------------------------

Note that you can also index your documents as JSON String and that you
don't have to give an ID:

[source,java]
--------------------------------------------------
String json = "{" +
        "\"user\":\"kimchy\"," +
        "\"postDate\":\"2013-01-30\"," +
        "\"message\":\"trying out Elastic Search\"," +
    "}";

IndexResponse response = client.prepareIndex("twitter", "tweet")
        .setSource(json)
        .execute()
        .actionGet();
--------------------------------------------------

`IndexResponse` object will give you report:

[source,java]
--------------------------------------------------
// Index name
String _index = response.index();
// Type name
String _type = response.type();
// Document ID (generated or not)
String _id = response.id();
// Version (if it's the first time you index this document, you will get: 1)
long _version = response.version();
--------------------------------------------------

If you use percolation while indexing, `IndexResponse` object will give
you percolator that have matched:

[source,java]
--------------------------------------------------
IndexResponse response = client.prepareIndex("twitter", "tweet", "1")
        .setSource(json)
        .setPercolate("*")
        .execute()
        .actionGet();

List<String> matches = response.matches();
--------------------------------------------------

For more information on the index operation, check out the REST
{ref}/docs-index_.html[index] docs.


=== Operation Threading

The index API allows to set the threading model the operation will be
performed when the actual execution of the API is performed on the same
node (the API is executed on a shard that is allocated on the same
server).

The options are to execute the operation on a different thread, or to
execute it on the calling thread (note that the API is still async). By
default, `operationThreaded` is set to `true` which means the operation
is executed on a different thread.

== Overview

Official low-level client for Elasticsearch. Its goal is to provide common
ground for all Elasticsearch-related code in JavaScript; because of this it tries
to be opinion-free and very extendable. The client works in both Node.js and browser environments.

It can be installed with:

[source,sh]
------------------------------------
npm install elasticsearch
------------------------------------

For browser usage, you can download the browser-ready build from the repository
or include it via CDN:

[source,html]
------------------------------------
<script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/@elastic/elasticsearch"></script>
------------------------------------

=== Example use

Simple use-case in Node.js:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
const { Client } = require('@elastic/elasticsearch');

// by default we connect to localhost:9200
const client = new Client();

async function run() {
  // Index a document
  const result = await client.index({
    index: 'my-index',
    id: '1',
    body: {
      any: 'data',
      timestamp: new Date()
    }
  });

  console.log(result);

  // Get the document
  const document = await client.get({
    index: 'my-index',
    id: '1'
  });

  console.log(document.body._source);
}

run().catch(console.log);
------------------------------------

Browser usage:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
const client = new Client({
  node: 'http://localhost:9200'
});

client.index({
  index: 'my-index',
  id: '1',
  body: {
    any: 'data',
    timestamp: new Date()
  }
}, function(error, response) {
  if (error) {
    console.error(error);
    return;
  }
  console.log(response);
});
------------------------------------

[NOTE] 
All the API calls map the raw REST API as closely as possible, including
the distinction between required and optional arguments to the calls.
The client supports both callback and Promise-based APIs.

=== Features

The client's features include:

* translating basic JavaScript data types to and from JSON
* configurable automatic discovery of cluster nodes
* persistent connections with keep-alive
* load balancing (with pluggable selection strategy) across all available nodes
* failed connection penalization (time based - failed connections won't be retried until a timeout is reached)
* Promise-based API with async/await support
* callback API for compatibility
* support for both Node.js and browser environments
* pluggable architecture
* connection pooling
* retry logic for failed requests
* support for HTTP compression
* request/response logging for debugging

=== Compatibility

The client supports different versions of Elasticsearch:
* Client version 7.x works with Elasticsearch 7.x
* Client version 6.x works with Elasticsearch 6.x
* Client version 5.x works with Elasticsearch 5.x

[NOTE]
We recommend using the same major version on client and cluster sides. You may hit some incompatibility issues when mixing major versions.

== Client

You can use the *JavaScript client* in multiple ways:

* Perform standard <<index_,index>>, <<get,get>>,
  <<delete,delete>> and <<search,search>> operations on an
  existing cluster
* Perform administrative tasks on a running cluster
* Connect to Elasticsearch from both Node.js applications and browser applications

Obtaining an elasticsearch `Client` is simple. The most common way to
get a client is by creating an instance with basic configuration:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
const { Client } = require('@elastic/elasticsearch');
const client = new Client();
------------------------------------

Or for more advanced configuration:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
const { Client } = require('@elastic/elasticsearch');
const client = new Client({
  node: 'https://localhost:9200',
  auth: {
    username: 'elastic',
    password: 'changeme'
  },
  ssl: {
    rejectUnauthorized: false
  }
});
------------------------------------

[[node-client]]
=== Node Client

For Node.js applications, install the client via npm:

[source,sh]
------------------------------------
npm install @elastic/elasticsearch
--------------------------------====

Then create a client instance:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
const { Client } = require('@elastic/elasticsearch');

// Basic connection to localhost:9200
const client = new Client();

// Connect to specific node(s)
const client = new Client({
  node: 'http://localhost:9200'
});

// Connect to multiple nodes (load balancing)
const client = new Client({
  nodes: [
    'http://localhost:9200',
    'http://localhost:9201',
    'http://localhost:9202'
  ]
});
------------------------------------

[[browser-client]]
=== Browser Client

For browser usage, you can include the client via CDN:

[source,html]
------------------------------------
<script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/@elastic/elasticsearch"></script>
------------------------------------

Then create a client instance:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
const client = new Client({
  node: 'http://localhost:9200'
});
------------------------------------

=== Client Configuration Options

The client accepts various configuration options:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
const client = new Client({
  // Elasticsearch node URL(s)
  node: 'http://localhost:9200', // single node
  // or
  nodes: ['http://localhost:9200', 'http://localhost:9201'], // multiple nodes
  
  // Authentication
  auth: {
    username: 'elastic',
    password: 'changeme'
  },
  
  // Optional authentication bearer token
  auth: {
    bearer: 'token'
  },
  
  // Request options
  requestTimeout: 30000,        // timeout in milliseconds
  pingTimeout: 3000,            // ping timeout
  sniffInterval: false,         // disable sniffing
  sniffOnStart: false,          // disable sniffing on start
  
  // SSL configuration
  ssl: {
    rejectUnauthorized: true,   // or false for self-signed certificates
    secureProtocol: 'TLSv1_2_method',
    ca: [fs.readFileSync('/path/to/ca.crt')],
    cert: fs.readFileSync('/path/to/client.crt'),
    key: fs.readFileSync('/path/to/client.key'),
    passphrase: 'client-key-password'
  },
  
  // Compression
  compression: 'gzip',          // or 'deflate' or false
  
  // Connection pool
  maxRetries: 3,                // number of retry attempts
  resurrectTimeout: 60000,      // revive timeout in milliseconds
  
  // Selectors
  randomizeHost: true,          // randomize hosts
  selector: 'roundRobin',       // or 'random'
  
  // Headers
  headers: {
    'x-elastic-client-meta': 'js=7.10.0'
  },
  
  // Proxy (Node.js only)
  proxy: 'http://proxy-server:8080',
  
  // Node filter
  nodeFilter: function (node) {
    // return true to disable the node
    return node.roles.master === false;
  },
  
  // Custom headers
  nodeSelector: 'roundRobin'    // or 'random' or custom function
});
------------------------------------

=== Authentication

The client supports several authentication methods:

==== Basic Authentication

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
const client = new Client({
  node: 'https://localhost:9200',
  auth: {
    username: 'elastic',
    password: 'changeme'
  }
});
------------------------------------

==== Bearer Token Authentication

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
const client = new Client({
  node: 'https://localhost:9200',
  auth: {
    bearer: 'your-bearer-token'
  }
});
------------------------------------

==== API Key Authentication (Elastic Cloud)

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
const client = new Client({
  node: 'https://your-cluster.es.io:9243',
  auth: {
    apiKey: 'base64EncodedApiKey'
  }
});
------------------------------------

=== Connection Management

The client automatically manages connections to Elasticsearch nodes:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
const { Client } = require('@elastic/elasticsearch');

const client = new Client({
  nodes: [
    'http://localhost:9200',
    'http://localhost:9201',
    'http://localhost:9202'
  ],
  // Connection pool configuration
  maxRetries: 3,
  resurrectTimeout: 60000,
  pingTimeout: 3000,
  requestTimeout: 30000
});

// Check cluster health
async function checkHealth() {
  try {
    const health = await client.cluster.health();
    console.log('Cluster status:', health.status);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Connection error:', error);
  }
}

checkHealth();
------------------------------------

=== Error Handling

The client provides detailed error information:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function handleErrors() {
  try {
    await client.get({
      index: 'nonexistent',
      id: '1'
    });
  } catch (error) {
    console.log('Error name:', error.name);          // 'ResponseError'
    console.log('Error message:', error.message);    // 'index_not_found_exception'
    console.log('Status code:', error.statusCode);   // 404
    console.log('Response body:', error.body);       // Error response
    
    // Check if it's a 404 error
    if (error.statusCode === 404) {
      console.log('Document not found');
    }
  }
}
------------------------------------

=== Logging

Enable logging for debugging:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
const { Client } = require('@elastic/elasticsearch');

const client = new Client({
  node: 'http://localhost:9200',
  log: 'trace',           // or 'debug', 'info', 'warning', 'error'
  // or custom logger
  log: {
    type: 'console',
    level: 'trace'
  },
  // or write to file
  log: {
    type: 'file',
    level: 'trace',
    path: 'elasticsearch.log'
  }
});
--------------------------------====

=== Cleanup

When shutting down your application, properly close the client:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function shutdown() {
  try {
    await client.close();
    console.log('Client closed successfully');
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error closing client:', error);
  }
}

// Call this when your application is shutting down
process.on('SIGINT', shutdown);
process.on('SIGTERM', shutdown);
--------------------------------===="},"timestamp":1763772971929,"session_id":"ae2075b6-f4ec-4598-9161-d2e00998a5bb"}

== Index API

The index API allows one to index a typed JSON document into a specific
index and make it searchable.

=== Index Document

The following example indexes a JSON document into an index called
twitter, under a type called tweet, with id valued 1:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function indexDocument() {
  const response = await client.index({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    body: {
      user: 'kimchy',
      postDate: new Date(),
      message: 'trying out Elasticsearch'
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Indexed:', response);
}

indexDocument();
------------------------------------

You can also index without providing an ID:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function indexDocumentWithoutId() {
  const response = await client.index({
    index: 'twitter',
    body: {
      user: 'kimchy',
      postDate: new Date(),
      message: 'trying out Elasticsearch'
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Document ID:', response.body._id);
}

indexDocumentWithoutId();
------------------------------------

=== Using Callbacks

If you prefer callbacks over promises:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
client.index({
  index: 'twitter',
  id: '1',
  body: {
    user: 'kimchy',
    postDate: new Date(),
    message: 'trying out Elasticsearch'
  }
}, function(error, response) {
  if (error) {
    console.error(error);
    return;
  }
  console.log('Indexed:', response);
});
------------------------------------

=== Response Structure

The index operation returns detailed information:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function handleIndexResponse() {
  const response = await client.index({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    body: {
      user: 'kimchy',
      postDate: new Date(),
      message: 'trying out Elasticsearch'
    }
  });
  
  // Document metadata
  console.log('Index:', response.body._index);     // 'twitter'
  console.log('Type:', response.body._type);       // '_doc'
  console.log('ID:', response.body._id);           // '1'
  console.log('Version:', response.body._version); // document version
  console.log('Result:', response.body.result);    // 'created' or 'updated'
  
  // Full response
  console.log(response.body);
}
------------------------------------

=== Automatic ID Generation

If you don't provide an ID, Elasticsearch automatically generates one:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function autoGeneratedId() {
  const response = await client.index({
    index: 'twitter',
    body: {
      user: 'kimchy',
      message: 'trying automatic ID generation'
    }
  });
  
  const generatedId = response.body._id;
  console.log('Generated ID:', generatedId);
  
  // Use the generated ID for future operations
  const document = await client.get({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: generatedId
  });
  
  console.log('Retrieved:', document.body._source);
}
------------------------------------

=== Routing

By default, document routing uses the document ID automatically. You can
specify custom routing:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function customRouting() {
  const response = await client.index({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    routing: 'user_kimchy',
    body: {
      user: 'kimchy',
      message: 'using custom routing'
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Indexed with routing:', response.body);
  
  // When querying, use the same routing for efficiency
  const document = await client.get({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    routing: 'user_kimchy'
  });
  
  console.log('Retrieved with routing:', document.body._source);
}
------------------------------------

=== Versioning

Elasticsearch provides built-in versioning. You can specify the version
when indexing:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function versionedIndexing() {
  // First create document
  await client.index({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    body: {
      user: 'kimchy',
      message: 'first version'
    }
  });
  
  try {
    // Try to update with wrong version
    await client.index({
      index: 'twitter',
      id: '1',
      version: 5,  // Wrong version - should be 2
      body: {
        user: 'kimchy',
        message: 'this should fail'
      }
    });
  } catch (error) {
    console.log('Version conflict:', error.body.error);
    
    // Try again with correct version
    const response = await client.index({
      index: 'twitter',
      id: '1',
      version: 2,
      body: {
        user: 'kimchy',
        message: 'second version'
      }
    });
    
    console.log('Successfully updated:', response.body);
  }
}
------------------------------------

=== Create Only

To create a document only if it doesn't already exist, use `create`:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function createOnly() {
  try {
    // First creation should succeed
    const firstCreate = await client.index({
      index: 'twitter',
      id: '1',
      body: {
        user: 'kimchy',
        message: 'original message'
      }
    });
    
    console.log('First create:', firstCreate.body.result);
    
    // Second attempt should fail
    const secondCreate = await client.index({
      index: 'twitter',
      id: '1',
      body: {
        user: 'kimchy',
        message: 'duplicate message'
      }
    });
    
  } catch (error) {
    console.log('Second create failed:', error.body.error);
    console.log('Status:', error.statusCode); // 409 Conflict
    
    // This would work - using op_type=create explicitly
    // let's delete first then create again
    await client.delete({
      index: 'twitter',
      id: '1'
    });
    
    const createResponse = await client.index({
      index: 'twitter',
      id: '1',
      body: {
        user: 'kimchy',
        message: 'new document after delete'
      }
    });
    
    console.log('New create result:', createResponse.body.result);
  }
}
------------------------------------

=== Wait for Active Shards

You can wait for a specified number of active shards before returning:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function waitForActiveShards() {
  const response = await client.index({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    body: {
      user: 'kimchy',
      message: 'waiting for active shards'
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Default indexing completed');
  
  // Wait for all primary shards
  const primaryResponse = await client.index({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '2',
    body: {
      user: 'kimchy',
      message: 'waiting for primary shards'
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Primary shard indexing completed');
}
------------------------------------

=== Refresh

Force a refresh of the index after indexing:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function indexAndRefresh() {
  await client.index({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    body: {
      user: 'kimchy',
      message: 'immediately searchable'
    },
    refresh: true  // Force refresh after indexing
  });
  
  // Document should be immediately available for search
  const searchResults = await client.search({
    index: 'twitter',
    body: {
      query: {
        match: {
          message: 'immediately searchable'
        }
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Search results:', searchResults.body.hits.hits.length);
}
------------------------------------

=== Timestamp

Automatically add a timestamp to your documents:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function timestampedDocument() {
  const response = await client.index({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    body: {
      user: 'kimchy',
      message: 'document with timestamp'
    },
    timestamp: new Date().toISOString()
  });
  
  console.log('Indexed with timestamp:', response.body);
}
------------------------------------

For more information on the index operation, check out the REST

== Get API

The get API allows you to retrieve a JSON document from the index based on its id.

=== Basic Get

The following example retrieves a JSON document with id 1 from an index called twitter:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function getDocument() {
  const response = await client.get({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1'
  });
  
  console.log('Document:', response.body._source);
  console.log('Index:', response.body._index);
  console.log('ID:', response.body._id);
  console.log('Version:', response.body._version);
}

getDocument();
------------------------------------

=== Real-time Get

By default, the get API is real-time, and is not affected by the refresh
rate of the index. When a document is updated, you can immediately retrieve
the updated version:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function realtimeGet() {
  // Index initial document
  await client.index({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    body: {
      user: 'kimchy',
      message: 'initial message'
    }
  });
  
  // Update document
  await client.index({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    body: {
      user: 'kimchy',
      message: 'updated message'
    }
  });
  
  // Immediately get the updated document
  const updatedDoc = await client.get({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1'
  });
  
  console.log('Message:', updatedDoc.body._source.message); // 'updated message'
}
------------------------------------

=== Source Filtering

You can control which fields are returned using `_source` parameter:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function sourceFiltering() {
  const response = await client.get({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    _source: 'user'  // Only return the 'user' field
  });
  
  console.log('Filtered source:', response.body._source); // { user: 'kimchy' }
  
  // Get multiple specific fields
  const multiFieldResponse = await client.get({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    _source: ['user', 'message']
  });
  
  console.log('Multi-field:', multiFieldResponse.body._source);
  
  // Exclude fields
  const excludeResponse = await client.get({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    _source: {
      excludes: ['postDate']
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Excluded fields:', excludeResponse.body._source);
}
------------------------------------

=== Routing

If you're using custom routing, you must provide the routing value when getting
the document:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function routedGet() {
  // Index with custom routing
  await client.index({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    routing: 'user_kimchy',
    body: {
      user: 'kimchy',
      message: 'document with custom routing'
    }
  });
  
  try {
    // This will fail without routing
    await client.get({
      index: 'twitter',
      id: '1'
    });
  } catch (error) {
    console.log('Error without routing:', error.body.error);
    
    // This will work with routing
    const response = await client.get({
      index: 'twitter',
      id: '1',
      routing: 'user_kimchy'
    });
    
    console.log('Successfully retrieved:', response.body._source.message);
  }
}
------------------------------------

=== Versioning

You can retrieve a specific version of a document:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function versionedGet() {
  // Index multiple versions
  const doc1 = await client.index({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    version: 1,
    body: {
      user: 'kimchy',
      message: 'version 1'
    }
  });
  
  const doc2 = await client.index({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    version: 2,
    body: {
      user: 'kimchy',
      message: 'version 2'
    }
  });
  
  // Get latest version
  const latest = await client.get({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1'
  });
  console.log('Latest message:', latest.body._source.message); // 'version 2'
  
  // Get specific version
  const version1 = await client.get({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    version: 1,
    version_type: 'external'
  });
  console.log('Version 1 message:', version1.body._source.message); // 'version 1'
}
------------------------------------

=== Preference

Control which shard to execute the get request on:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function preferenceGet() {
  // Execute only on primary shard
  const primaryResponse = await client.get({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    preference: '_primary'
  });
  
  // Execute on specific local shard
  const localResponse = await client.get({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    preference: '_local'
  });
  
  // Execute on specific node (only works if you know the node name)
  const nodeResponse = await client.get({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    preference: '_only:some-node-name'
  });
  
  // Execute with custom preference
  const customResponse = await client.get({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    preference: 'my-custom-preference'
  });
}
------------------------------------

=== Stored Fields

Retrieve stored fields instead of `_source`:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function storedFields() {
  // Index document with stored fields
  await client.index({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    body: {
      user: 'kimchy',
      message: 'hello world',
      postDate: new Date()
    }
  });
  
  // Get only stored fields
  const response = await client.get({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    stored_fields: 'user,message'
  });
  
  console.log('Stored fields:', response.body.fields);
  // fields will contain user and message fields but not the _source
}
------------------------------------

=== NotFound Handling

Handle cases where a document doesn't exist:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function notFoundHandling() {
  try {
    const response = await client.get({
      index: 'twitter',
      id: 'nonexistent-id'
    });
    console.log('Found:', response.body);
  } catch (error) {
    if (error.statusCode === 404) {
      console.log('Document not found');
      console.log('Found status:', error.body.found); // false
      console.log('Index exists:', error.body._index !== undefined);
    } else {
      console.error('Other error:', error);
    }
  }
}

=== Real-time Performance

For performance considerations with real-time gets:

[source,javascript]

async function performanceExample() {
  await client.index({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    body: {
      user: 'kimchy',
      message: 'performance test'
    },
    refresh: 'wait_for'  // Wait for refresh before returning
  });
  
  // The get will be highly performant since we waited for refresh
  const response = await client.get({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    preference: '_local'  // Use local shard for better performance
  });
  
  console.log('Response time optimization applied');
  console.log('Document:', response.body._source);
}

== Search API

The search API allows you to execute a search query and get back search hits
that match the query.

=== Basic Search

The following example searches for documents in the twitter index:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function basicSearch() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'twitter',
    body: {
      query: {
        match: {
          message: 'elasticsearch'
        }
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Total hits:', response.body.hits.total);
  console.log('Documents:', response.body.hits.hits.map(hit => hit._source));
}

basicSearch();
------------------------------------

=== URI Search

You can also execute searches using the URI search API:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function uriSearch() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'twitter',
    q: 'message:elasticsearch'
  });
  
  console.log('URI search results:', response.body.hits.hits);
}
------------------------------------

=== Multi Index Search

Search across multiple indices:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function multiIndexSearch() {
  // Search on twitter and blog indices
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'twitter,blog',
    body: {
      query: {
        match_all: {}
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Multi-index hits:', response.body.hits.hits.length);
  
  // Search on all indices
  const allIndicesResponse = await client.search({
    index: '_all',
    body: {
      query: {
        match_all: {}
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('All indices hits:', allIndicesResponse.body.hits.hits.length);
}
------------------------------------

=== Pagination and Sorting

Control the number of results returned and their order:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function paginatedSearch() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'twitter',
    size: 10,  // Number of results to return
    from: 0,   // Starting offset
    body: {
      query: {
        match_all: {}
      },
      sort: [
        { postDate: { order: 'desc' } },
        { _score: { order: 'desc' } }
      ]
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Documents:', response.body.hits.hits);
  console.log('Total available:', response.body.hits.total);
}

=== Field Selection

Control which fields to return in the search results:

------------------------------------
async function fieldSelection() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'twitter',
    body: {
      query: {
        match_all: {}
      },
      _source: ['user', 'message'],  // Only return these fields
      fields: ['postDate']           // Also return stored fields
    }
  });
  
  response.body.hits.hits.forEach(hit => {
    console.log('Source fields:', hit._source);
    console.log('Stored fields:', hit.fields);
  });
}

=== Filtering and Scoring

async function filteredSearch() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'twitter',
    body: {
      query: {
        bool: {
          must: [
            {
              match: {
                message: 'elasticsearch'
              }
            }
          ],
          filter: [
            {
              range: {
                postDate: {
                  gte: '2020-01-01'
                }
              }
            }
          ]
        }
      }
    }
  });

}

=== Aggregations

Perform data aggregation with search:

async function aggregationSearch() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'twitter',
    size: 0,  // Don't return documents, just aggregations
    body: {
      query: {
        match_all: {}
      },
      aggs: {
        users: {
          terms: {
            field: 'user.keyword'
          },
          aggs: {
            avg_date: {
              avg: {
                field: 'postDate'
              }
            }
          }
        },
        date_histogram: {
          date_histogram: {
            field: 'postDate',
            calendar_interval: 'day'
          }
        }
      }
    }
  });

  console.log('Date histogram:', response.body.aggregations.date_histogram.buckets);
}

=== Search Template

Use parameterized search templates:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function templateSearch() {
  // First, store a search template
  await client.putScript({
    id: 'search_by_user',
    body: {
      script: {
        lang: 'mustache',
        source: {
          query: {
            match: {
              user: '{{user}}'
            }
          },
          size: '{{size}}'
        }
      }
    }
  });
  
  // Then execute the search template
  const response = await client.searchTemplate({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: 'search_by_user',
    body: {
      params: {
        user: 'kimchy',
        size: 10
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Template search results:', response.body.hits.hits);
}
--------------------------------=== Point in Time

Execute searches using Point in Time (PIT):

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function pitSearch() {
  // Create a Point in Time
  const pitResponse = await client.openPointInTime({
    index: 'twitter',
    keep_alive: '1m'
  });
  
  const pitId = pitResponse.body.id;
  
  // Search using the PIT
  const response = await client.search({
    body: {
      size: 10,
      query: {
        match_all: {}
      },
      pit: {
        id: pitId,
        keep_alive: '1m'
      },
      sort: [{ _id: 'asc' }]
    }
  });
  
  console.log('First page:', response.body.hits.hits);
  
  // Get sort values for pagination
  const lastHit = response.body.hits.hits[response.body.hits.hits.length - 1];
  const sortValues = lastHit.sort;
  
  // Search for next page
  const nextPageResponse = await client.search({
    body: {
      size: 10,
      query: {
        match_all: {}
      },
      pit: {
        id: pitId,
        keep_alive: '1m'
      },
      sort: [{ _id: 'asc' }],
      search_after: sortValues
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Second page:', nextPageResponse.body.hits.hits);
  
  // Don't forget to close the PIT
  await client.closePointInTime({
    body: {
      id: pitId
    }
  });
}
------------------------------------

=== Async Search

Execute long-running searches asynchronously:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function asyncSearch() {
  // Submit async search
  const submitResponse = await client.submitAsyncSearch({
    index: 'twitter',
    body: {
      query: {
        match_all: {}
      },
      size: 1000,
      timeout: '10m'  // Long timeout for complex query
    },
    wait_for_completion_timeout: '0s'  // Don't wait for completion
  });
  
  const searchId = submitResponse.body.id;
  console.log('Async search submitted:', searchId);
  
  // Check status
  const statusResponse = await client.asyncSearchStatus({
    id: searchId
  });
  
  console.log('Search status:', statusResponse.body.is_running);
  
  // Get results when ready
  const resultsResponse = await client.getAsyncSearch({
    id: searchId,
    wait_for_completion_timeout: '30s'
  });
  
  console.log('Final results:', resultsResponse.body.response.hits.total);
  
  // Clean up async search
  await client.deleteAsyncSearch({
    id: searchId
  });
}
------------------------------------

== Delete API

The delete API allows you to delete a typed JSON document from a specific index based on its id.

=== Basic Delete

The following example deletes a JSON document with id 1 from an index called twitter:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function deleteDocument() {
  try {
    const response = await client.delete({
      index: 'twitter',
      id: '1'
    });
    
    console.log('Deleted successfully');
    console.log('Result:', response.body.result); // 'deleted'
    console.log('Version:', response.body._version); // document version
  } catch (error) {
    if (error.statusCode === 404) {
      console.log('Document not found');
    } else {
      console.error('Delete failed:', error);
    }
  }
}

deleteDocument();
------------------------------------

=== Versioning

Delete operations support versioning. You can specify the version to ensure
you're deleting the correct version:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function versionedDelete() {
  try {
    // Try to delete with wrong version
    const response = await client.delete({
      index: 'twitter',
      id: '1',
      version: 5  // Wrong version
    });
    
    console.log('Delete response:', response.body.result);
  } catch (error) {
    if (error.statusCode === 409) {
      console.log('Version conflict:', error.body.error);
      
      // Try with correct version (assuming current version is 1)
      const correctResponse = await client.delete({
        index: 'twitter',
        id: '1',
        version: 1
      });
      
      console.log('Deleted successfully:', correctResponse.body.result);
    }
  }
}
------------------------------------

=== Routing

If you're using custom routing, you must provide the routing value when deleting:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function routedDelete() {
  // Index with custom routing
  await client.index({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    routing: 'user_kimchy',
    body: {
      user: 'kimchy',
      message: 'document with custom routing'
    }
  });
  
  try {
    // This will fail without routing
    await client.delete({
      index: 'twitter',
      id: '1'
    });
  } catch (error) {
    console.log('Error without routing:', error.body.error);
    
    // This will work with routing
    const response = await client.delete({
      index: 'twitter',
      id: '1',
      routing: 'user_kimchy'
    });
    
    console.log('Deleted successfully with routing:', response.body.result);
  }
}
------------------------------------

=== Wait for Active Shards

You can wait for a specified number of active shards before completing the delete:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function waitForActiveShards() {
  const response = await client.delete({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    wait_for_active_shards: 1  // Wait for 1 active shard
  });
  
  console.log('Delete completed:', response.body.result);
}
------------------------------------

=== Refresh

Force a refresh after deletion:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function deleteAndRefresh() {
  const response = await client.delete({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    refresh: true  // Force refresh after deletion
  });
  
  console.log('Deleted and refreshed:', response.body.result);
  
  // Document should be immediately unavailable for search
  const searchResults = await client.search({
    index: 'twitter',
    body: {
      query: {
        term: {
          _id: '1'
        }
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Search results after delete:', searchResults.body.hits.total); // 0
}
------------------------------------

=== Timeout

Set a timeout for the delete operation:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function deleteWithTimeout() {
  try {
    const response = await client.delete({
      index: 'twitter',
      id: '1',
      timeout: '5s'
    });
    
    console.log('Deleted successfully:', response.body.result);
  } catch (error) {
    if (error.message.includes('timeout')) {
      console.log('Delete operation timed out');
    } else {
      console.error('Delete failed:', error);
    }
  }
}
------------------------------------

=== Delete Non-existent Document

Handle attempts to delete documents that don't exist:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function deleteNonExistent() {
  try {
    const response = await client.delete({
      index: 'twitter',
      id: 'nonexistent-id'
    });
    
    console.log('Delete response:', response.body);
  } catch (error) {
    console.log('Error status:', error.statusCode); // 404
    console.log('Error found:', error.body.found); // false
    console.log('Error message:', error.body.error);
  }
}
------------------------------------

=== Preference

Control which shard the delete operation executes on:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function preferenceDelete() {
  const response = await client.delete({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    preference: '_local'  // Execute on local shard
  });
  
  console.log('Deleted with preference:', response.body.result);
}
------------------------------------

=== Real-time Delete

Delete operations are real-time, affecting immediately available:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function realtimeDelete() {
  // Index a document
  await client.index({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1',
    body: {
      user: 'kimchy',
      message: 'test data'
    }
  });
  
  // Immediately delete it
  const deleteResponse = await client.delete({
    index: 'twitter',
    id: '1'
  });
  
  console.log('Delete result:', deleteResponse.body.result);
  
  // Try to get the deleted document
  try {
    await client.get({
      index: 'twitter',
      id: '1'
    });
  } catch (error) {
    console.log('Document not found after delete:', error.statusCode); // 404
  }
}
------------------------------------

=== Delete by Query

For more complex deletion scenarios, use delete by query:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function deleteByQuery() {
  // Delete all documents matching criteria
  const response = await client.deleteByQuery({
    index: 'twitter',
    body: {
      query: {
        term: {
          user: 'deprecated_user'
        }
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Documents deleted:', response.body.deleted);
  console.log('Took milliseconds:', response.body.took);
}
--------------------------------=== Response Structure

The delete API response contains useful metadata:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function examineDeleteResponse() {
  try {
    const response = await client.delete({
      index: 'twitter',
      id: '1'
    });
    
    console.log('Index:', response.body._index);
    console.log('Type:', response.body._type);
    console.log('ID:', response.body._id);
    console.log('Version:', response.body._version);
    console.log('Result:', response.body.result); // 'deleted'
    console.log('Shards:', response.body._shards);
    console.log('Sequence number:', response.body._seq_no);
    console.log('Primary term:', response.body._primary_term);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Delete failed:', error);
  }
}
------------------------------------

=== Error Handling

Proper error handling for delete operations:

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function robustDelete() {
  const indexName = 'twitter';
  const documentId = '1';
  
  try {
    const response = await client.delete({
      index: indexName,
      id: documentId
    });
    
    console.log(`Document ${documentId} in ${indexName} deleted successfully`);
    return true;
    
  } catch (error) {
    switch (error.statusCode) {
      case 404:
        console.log(`Document ${documentId} not found in ${indexName}`);
        return false;
        
      case 409:
        console.log(`Version conflict for document ${documentId} in ${indexName}`);
        return false;
        
      case 412:
        console.log(`Precondition failed for document ${documentId} in ${indexName}`);
        return false;
        
      default:
        console.error(`Unexpected error deleting document ${documentId}:`, error.message);
        throw error;
    }
  }
}
------------------------------------

== Query DSL - Queries

The Query DSL (Domain Specific Language) is Elasticsearch's JSON-based
query language. It allows you to compose complex queries by combining
various query and filter clauses.

=== Match Query

The match query is the standard query for performing full-text searches,
including handling fuzzy matching and phrase matching.

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function matchQuery() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'twitter',
    body: {
      query: {
        match: {
          message: 'elasticsearch is powerful'
        }
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Match query results:', response.body.hits.total);
}

matchQuery();
------------------------------------

=== Term Query

The term query finds documents that contain the exact term specified.

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function termQuery() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'twitter',
    body: {
      query: {
        term: {
          'user.keyword': 'kimchy'
        }
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Term query results:', response.body.hits.total);
}

termQuery();
------------------------------------

=== Terms Query

The terms query finds documents that contain any of the specified terms.

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function termsQuery() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'twitter',
    body: {
      query: {
        terms: {
          'user.keyword': ['kimchy', 'john', 'jane']
        }
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Terms query results:', response.body.hits.total);
}

termsQuery();
------------------------------------

            lte: '2020-12-31'
          }
        }
      }

}

rangeQuery();

=== Query String Query

The query string query allows for using the Lucene query parser syntax.

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function queryStringQuery() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'twitter',
    body: {
      query: {
        query_string: {
          default_field: 'message',
          query: '(elasticsearch AND powerful) OR (search AND engine)'
        }
      }
    }

=== Bool Query

The bool query combines multiple query clauses with boolean logic.

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function boolQuery() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'twitter',
    body: {
      query: {
        bool: {
          must: [
            {
              match: {
                message: 'elasticsearch'
              }
            }
          ],
          filter: [
            {
              term: {
                'user.keyword': 'kimchy'
              }
            }
          ],
          should: [
            {
              match: {
                message: 'powerful'
              }
            }
          ],
          must_not: [
            {
              term: {
                status: 'deleted'
              }
            }
          ]
        }
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Bool query results:', response.body.hits.total);
}

boolQuery();
------------------------------------

        }

=== Nested Query

The nested query allows you to query against nested documents.

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function nestedQuery() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'products',
    body: {
      query: {
        nested: {
          path: 'features',
          query: {
            bool: {
              must: [
                {
                  match: {
                    'features.name': 'color'
                  }
                },
                {
                  match: {
                    'features.value': 'red'
                  }
                }
              ]
            }
          }
        }
      }
    }
  });

}

--------------------------------=== Constant Score Query

The constant score query wraps another query and returns all documents
with a constant score equal to the query boost.

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function constantScoreQuery() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'twitter',
    body: {
      query: {
        constant_score: {
          filter: {
            term: {
              status: 'published'
            }
          },
          boost: 1.2
        }
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Constant score query results:', response.body.hits.total);
}

constantScoreQuery();
------------------------------------

=== Function Score Query

The function score query allows you to modify the score of documents
that are retrieved by a query.

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function functionScoreQuery() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'twitter',
    body: {
      query: {
        function_score: {
          query: {
            match: {
              message: 'elasticsearch'
            }
          },
          functions: [
            {
              script_score: {
                script: {
                  source: "doc['views'].value * 0.1",
                  params: {
                    factor: 0.1
                  }
                }
              }
            }
          ],
          boost: 5
        }
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Function score query results:', response.body.hits.hits.map(
    hit => ({ score: hit._score, message: hit._source.message })
  ));
}

functionScoreQuery();
------------------------------------

=== Dis Max Query

The dis max query returns documents matching one or more wrapped queries,
with the score from the query with the highest score.

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function disMaxQuery() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'twitter',
    body: {
      query: {
        dis_max: {
          queries: [
            {
              match: {
                message: 'elasticsearch'
              }
            },
            {
              match: {
                user: 'kimchy'
              }
            }
          ],
          tie_breaker: 0.3
        }
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Dis max query results:', response.body.hits.total);
}

disMaxQuery();
------------------------------------

=== Boosting Query

The boosting query returns documents matching a positive query, but
reduces the score of documents that also match a negative query.

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function boostingQuery() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'twitter',
    body: {
      query: {
        boosting: {
          positive: {
            match: {
              message: 'elasticsearch'
            }
          },
          negative: {
            match: {
              message: 'testing'
            }
          },
          negative_boost: 0.2
        }
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Boosting query results:', response.body.hits.total);
}

boostingQuery();
------------------------------------

=== IDs Query

The IDs query returns documents based on their document IDs.

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function idsQuery() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'twitter',
    body: {
      query: {
        ids: {
          values: ['1', '2', '3']
        }
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('IDs query results:', response.body.hits.total);
}

idsQuery();
------------------------------------

=== Common Terms Query

The common terms query provides more preference to uncommon words.

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function commonTermsQuery() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'twitter',
    body: {
      query: {
        common: {
          message: {
            query: 'elasticsearch is a powerful search engine',
            cutoff_frequency: 0.001
          }
        }
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Common terms query results:', response.body.hits.total);
}

commonTermsQuery();

== Query DSL - Filters

While both filters and queries can be used for searching, filters are
generally preferred for restricting the result set because they are
cached and faster than queries. Filters work with exact values and do not
calculate relevance scores.

NOTE: In Elasticsearch 6.x and later, the distinction between queries and
filters has been unified. Most previously filter-only queries can now be
used in filter contexts.

=== Term Filter

The term filter finds documents that contain the exact term specified.

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function termFilter() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'twitter',
    body: {
      query: {
        bool: {
          filter: [
            {
              term: {
                'user.keyword': 'kimchy'
              }
            }
          ]
        }
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Term filter results:', response.body.hits.total);
}

termFilter();
------------------------------------

The terms filter finds documents that contain any of the specified terms.

async function notFilter() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'twitter',
    body: {
      query: {
        bool: {
          must_not: [
            {
              term: {
                status: 'deleted'
              }
            }
          ]
        }
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Not filter results:', response.body.hits.total);
}

notFilter();
------------------------------------

=== Geo Bounding Box Filter

The geo bounding box filter matches documents with geopoint values that
fall within the specified rectangle.

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function geoBoundingBoxFilter() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'locations',
    body: {
      query: {
        bool: {
          filter: [
            {
              geo_bounding_box: {
                'location': {
                  top_left: '41.0,-74.0',
                  bottom_right: '40.0,-73.0'
                }
              }
            }
          ]
        }
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Geo bounding box filter results:', response.body.hits.total);
}

geoBoundingBoxFilter();
------------------------------------

=== Geo Distance Filter

The geo distance filter matches documents with geopoint values within a
certain distance from a central point.

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function geoDistanceFilter() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'locations',
    body: {
      query: {
        bool: {
          filter: [
            {
              geo_distance: {
                distance: '1000m',
                location: '40.7128,-74.0060' // New York City
              }
            }
          ]
        }
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Geo distance filter results:', response.body.hits.total);
}

geoDistanceFilter();
------------------------------------

=== Geo Polygon Filter

The geo polygon filter matches documents with geopoint values that fall
within the specified polygon.

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function geoPolygonFilter() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'locations',
    body: {
      query: {
        bool: {
          filter: [
            {
              geo_polygon: {
                location: {
                  points: [
                    '40.7128,-74.0060',
                    '40.7589,-73.9851',
                    '40.7796,-73.9632',
                    '40.7527,-73.9770'
                  ]
                }
              }
            }
          ]
        }
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Geo polygon filter results:', response.body.hits.total);
}

geoPolygonFilter();
------------------------------------

=== Script Filter

The script filter allows you to use script expressions for filtering.

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function scriptFilter() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'products',
    body: {
      query: {
        bool: {
          filter: [
            {
              script: {
                script: {
                  source: "doc['price'].value > params.threshold",
                  params: {
                    threshold: 1000
                  },
                  lang: 'painless'
                }
              }
            }
          ]
        }
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Script filter results:', response.body.hits.total);
}

scriptFilter();
------------------------------------

=== Has Child Filter

The has child filter returns parent documents which have child documents
matching the query.

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function hasChildFilter() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'companies',
    body: {
      query: {
        bool: {
          filter: [
            {
              has_child: {
                type: 'employee',
                query: {
                  bool: {
                    filter: [
                      {
                        term: {
                          department: 'engineering'
                        }
                      }
                    ]
                  }
                }
              }
            }
          ]
        }
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Has child filter results:', response.body.hits.total);
}

hasChildFilter();
------------------------------------

=== Has Parent Filter

The has parent filter returns child documents which parent documents
match the query.

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function hasParentFilter() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'employees',
    body: {
      query: {
        bool: {
          filter: [
            {
              has_parent: {
                parent_type: 'company',
                query: {
                  bool: {
                    filter: [
                      {
                        term: {
                          industry: 'technology'
                        }
                      }
                    ]
                  }
                }
              }
            }
          ]
        }
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Has parent filter results:', response.body.hits.total);
}

hasParentFilter();
------------------------------------

=== Type Filter

The type filter filters documents based on their type (for indices with
multiple types, which is deprecated in newer versions).

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function typeFilter() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'my-index',
    body: {
      query: {
        bool: {
          filter: [
            {
              type: {
                value: 'tweet'
              }
            }
          ]
        }
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Type filter results:', response.body.hits.total);
}

typeFilter();
------------------------------------

=== Indices Filter

The indices filter filters documents based on the indices they belong to.

[source,javascript]
------------------------------------
async function indicesFilter() {
  const response = await client.search({
    index: 'twitter,blog',
    body: {
      query: {
        indices: {
          indices: ['twitter'],
          query: {
            bool: {
              filter: [
                {
                  term: {
                    'user.keyword': 'kimchy'
                  }
                }
              ]
            }
          },
          no_match_query: {
            match_all: {}
          }
        }
      }
    }
  });
  
  console.log('Indices filter results:', response.body.hits.total);
}

indicesFilter();
